channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 俄罗斯间谍回来了，而且比以往任何时候都更危险 👇

Russian spies are back—and more dangerous than ever https://t.co/485mx1krK7 👇

item.title: 印度新富起来的精英们比老一代更年轻、更喜欢冒险。走进疯狂的印度富人世界： 👇
item.description:
India’s new wealthy elites are younger and more adventurous than the old lot. Head inside the world of crazy rich Indians: https://t.co/Ip7ORYRi1V 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 这份小报依然是坚定的保守派，但它的版面却比以前更加轻松、明亮和温和。它的重塑是英国社会显著自由化的一个案例研究👇。
item.description:
The tabloid is still staunchly conservative, but its pages are lighter, brighter and gentler than they once were. Its remaking is a case study in the remarkable liberalisation of British society https://t.co/jzvQtSRmzl 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 今天的 "情报 "节目：欧洲不受欢迎的绿党、全球最大奇观制造商的科技赌博以及加布里埃尔-加西亚-马尔克斯的新书。收听每日播客： 👇
item.description:
Today on “The Intelligence”: Europe’s unpopular green parties, the world’s largest spectacle-maker’s tech gamble and Gabriel García Márquez’s new book. Listen to the daily podcast: https://t.co/mj6HC6RXZZ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 世事变迁 👇
item.description:
Things have changed https://t.co/Dv5W6IZ0Ia 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 自乌克兰被入侵以来的两年里，俄罗斯的经济屡次战胜了预言家。韧性的背后是什么？ 👇
item.description:
In the two years since the invasion of Ukraine, Russia’s economy has repeatedly defied the doomsayers.

Now Vladimir Putin seems to have inflation under control. What is behind the resilience? https://t.co/JofdKETyuh 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 试图用经过实验室测试的、根据患者个人需求量身定制的补充剂来阻止认知能力下降是一回事。在不知道未来会有什么风险的情况下刺激未受损的大脑则是另一回事👇。
item.description:
Trying to arrest cognitive decline with lab-tested supplements tailored to an individual patient’s needs is one thing. Stimulating an unimpaired brain without knowing what risks lie down the road is another https://t.co/wW4qcl2dqq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 数百万中国人将毕生积蓄投入到可能永远无法建成的房产中。1843 》杂志采访了心怀不满的准居民 👇 。
item.description:
Millions of Chinese people have ploughed their life savings into properties that may never get built. 1843 magazine talks to disgruntled would-be residents https://t.co/Ka3kSYQ8OA 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: "我们正在谈论的可能是人类历史的终结。不是历史的终结，只是人类主导部分的终结，"尤瓦尔-诺亚-哈拉里（Yuval Noah Harari）在一篇特邀文章👇 中谈到人工智能时说。
item.description:
“What we are talking about is potentially the end of human history. Not the end of history, just the end of its human-dominated part,” Yuval Noah Harari says of AI in a guest essay https://t.co/gKIvoEe6GR 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.description:
People in Asia sleep later, shorter and less well https://t.co/pH52hYa3Yr 👇

item.title: 在过去的半个世纪里，葡萄牙政治一直令人感到乏味。但最近的选举让一切都发生了变化 👇
item.description:
Portuguese politics had been reassuringly boring for the past half-century. But the recent election has shaken things up https://t.co/RhbZvujRUE 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 从唐纳德-特朗普（Donald Trump）、彼得-蒂尔（Peter Thiel）到阿卜杜勒-法塔赫-塞西（Abdel Fattah el-Sisi），每个人都想建立新的城市👇。
item.description:
Firms and governments are planning more settlements than at any time in the post-war period, with many already under construction.

Everyone, from Donald Trump and Peter Thiel to Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, wants to start new cities https://t.co/rSvtNEQzhD 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 在许多著名的博物馆中，有许多东西从未展出过。在仓库中，珍宝通常会受到保护，但老旧的保险库已经满了，非常危险。解决办法之一就是搬家：
item.description:
At many acclaimed museums, a whole lot is never on view. In stor­age treasures are usually protected, but the old vaults are dangerously full. One solution is to move house: https://t.co/dVmUz2796w pic.twitter.com/MVqrgcFznt

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 冷战期间，西方情报机构资助作家，有时是非常优秀的作家。以下是六本你不知道的宣传书籍 👇
item.description:
During the cold war Western intelligence agencies subsidised authors, sometimes very good ones. Here are six books you didn’t know were propaganda https://t.co/aGKNjuJW5V 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 这六本书有助于解释中东一个世纪的暴力事件 👇

These six books help explain a century of violence in the Middle East https://t.co/pRn29n1FA1 👇

item.title: 实现停火并非不可能。然而，随着斋月的开始，情况可能会更加暗淡 👇。
item.description:
It is still not impossible that a ceasefire could be struck. Yet as Ramadan begins the picture could hardly be bleaker https://t.co/NIR4Q3cAPm 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: "奥本海默》既是一部群众喜闻乐见的大片，也是一部影评人喜闻乐见的激情之作。也许它的成功会说服好莱坞投资拍摄一些更有特色的电影 👇
item.description:
“Oppenheimer” is both a crowd-pleasing blockbuster and a critic-pleasing passion project. Perhaps its success will persuade Hollywood to invest in some more distinctive films https://t.co/JB4SES8PJD 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 通过打造世界领先的赛事--印度板球管理委员会再次向对手发出挑战，要求他们想办法跟上🏏。
item.description:
By building a world-leading tournament—again—the Board of Control for Cricket in India has challenged its rivals to find a way to keep up https://t.co/aChEqi7Dxo 🏏

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 姜黄正在杀人。发展中国家--尤其是印度--应该学习孟加拉国公开、务实的尝试，防止这种情况发生👇。
item.description:
Turmeric is killing people. Developing countries—especially India—should learn from Bangladesh’s open, pragmatic attempts to prevent this from happening https://t.co/PZYkpbhuvV 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 牛肉每卡路里食物排放的二氧化碳是豆腐的 31 倍。人类烹饪这么多牛，也是在烹饪自己。放弃牛排可能是减少我们碳足迹的最有效方法之一👇。
item.description:
Beef emits 31 times more CO₂ per calorie of food than tofu does. By cooking so many cows, humans are cooking themselves, too. Forgoing steaks may be one of the most efficient ways to reduce our carbon footprint https://t.co/N4R7YEPoGH 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 性问题被认为是造成五分之一到一半离婚的原因。减少这一数字将使许多成人和儿童免于痛苦和贫困👇。
item.description:
Sexual issues are thought to contribute to between a ﬁfth and half of all divorces. Reducing that number would spare many adults and children from misery and impoverishment https://t.co/wO5rIrZtcS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 中层管理者常常被认为是懒惰的。事实上，他们有一个共同的问题👇。
item.description:
Middle managers are often presumed to be lazy. In fact, they are suffering from a common problem https://t.co/aEBRHNN7eu 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 中国正处于低谷。许多人缺乏消费或投资的信心，也不太明白出了什么问题。高层官员无法承认这一点，因为权力集中在一个人身上。怀疑他是禁忌 👇
item.description:
China is in a funk. Many people lack the conﬁdence to spend or invest, and do not quite understand what has gone wrong. Senior oﬃcials cannot acknowledge this, because power is so centralised in one man. And doubting him is taboo https://t.co/n7OcOm1Ps9 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 以色列在道义上有责任防止加沙发生饥荒。它也有这样做的法律义务。现在，乔-拜登在纵容以色列的行为数月之后，又在寻找变通办法来免除它的责任👇。
item.description:
Israel has a moral duty to prevent famine in Gaza. It also has a legal obligation to do so. Now, after enabling Israel’s behaviour for months, Joe Biden is looking for workarounds that will absolve it of responsibility https://t.co/Yx89sUTj0r 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 您已经看完《接班人》。到哪里再去了解权力争夺和权力午餐？这里有四本书和一个播客可以满足您的渴望👇。
item.description:
You’ve finished “Succession”. Where to get another fix of power grabs and power lunches? Here are four books and one podcast to satisfy your craving https://t.co/rCalN0NnmB 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: "对第三方选民最大的误解是，如果他们不把选票投给第三方候选人，他们就会把选票投给民主党或共和党"。@daniella_raz在 "制衡 "节目中与@imkahloon对话 🎧
item.description:
“The biggest misconception about third-party voters is this idea that if they had not cast a ballot for a third-party candidate, they would have instead voted for a Democrat or Republican.” @daniella_raz talks to @imkahloon on “Checks and Balance” https://t.co/a2eG1xlxV5 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024

item.title: 许多人在离开大学时都背负着沉重的债务，获得的学位也只是一个无关紧要的、教学质量很差的学位。他们被骗了，没有为更好的生活做好准备👇。
item.description:
Many leave university loaded with debt and equipped with a degree of peripheral relevance that has been taught badly. They are being ripped off, not prepared for a better life https://t.co/vsF95iXjFO 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 12, 2024
